Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2010 08:07PM billiegirl wrote: I tried neurontin, prozac & some OTC herbs. Nada. Then started taking 1000mg daily of Acai Berry. Took about 2-3 weeks to stop the hot flashes completely!
Posts.Title: Hotflashes alaskalady SusieMTN

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 02:17PM - edited Sep 27, 2011 02:18PM by billiegirl I was diagnoised with severe sleep apnea and am on a C-Pap machine at the highest setting. Have been using it for 2 years. Amazing...I am now afraid to even nap without it. Sleep better and now, no more falling asleep or feeling constantly exhaused during the days. I don't know who invented the idea...but I love mine. For many years I woke up everyday with a headache, dry mouth & sore throat. As soon as I started using the C-pap the chronic head-aches and mouth problems went away.
Posts.Title: Sleep apnea rkt cliff

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2009 11:18AM - edited Aug 30, 2009 11:19AM by billiegirl I had 30+ positive nodes. Did not receive chemo prior to surgery but had 4 AC & 4 Tax post-mastectomy. Then rads. Did not start Herceptin until a year later. My dx will have been 5 years ago as of 9/21. Was dx with IDC but I still believe it was IBC. The tumor was actually very tiny (less than 2cm) but aggressive, yet I had extreme external symptoms (flu-like feeling for almost 3 months, painful enlarged breast, red ,hot, inflammed skin over entire breast) Had neg mammo after symptoms began and was specifically told it was not IBC. Several drs insisted I had mastititis or dermatitis. Currently NED as far as breast cancer. Have had other major health problems, but not breast cancer related. KerryMac...thanks for posting the link to that article. It was informative and encouraging.Michele, hang in there and think positive. Treatments keep getting better and better and also much easier to tolerate. Sounds like 10-20 years ago we would have had little hope for long term survival. Every day is a gift!
Posts.Title: Large amount of nodes removed and positive. michele54 London-Virginia

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 04:22AM billiegirl wrote: I was/am in a vaccine trial at the University of Washington in Seattle. I received 2 doses in 2006. I am still NED. Originally has Breast Ca in 30 plus nodes in 2004.
Posts.Title: Landmark Cancer Vaccine Trial Nancylm billiegirl

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 04:13PM billiegirl wrote: I had a DNR placed on the hospital record a few years back when things were going rough and it did not seem like it would get better. However I did survive with-out major intervention, regained strength and some stamina and came home. Then last year I went in for a minor hernia repair. On the spur of the moment, just before I went to the OR, I changed that DNR to FULL CODE. Well, I had a respiratory arrest in recovery and ended up on a vent for 1 week and in ICU. However, I have fully recovered from that incident, live by myself, care for myself and am happy & content despite being somewhat worse for wear.I still have quality of life and much joy. I would not do another DNR unless I have enrolled in Hospice or Palliative care. If I had not changed my DNR status just before that last surgery, they would have "let me go".
Posts.Title: DNR Paula1628 Padiddle
I dont have a PCP,Im trying to figure out the results myself... blackhotflame momzybaby

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2009 04:09PM billiegirl wrote: Most Docs just need the report, as the reports are read and studied by a radiologist to begin with, in order to write the report. If they need the films, they are usually ordered by mail or courier. It is rare that the patient has to pick them up and hand carry them.Most Docs are not specialist at reading the films, though they do often want to see them. The Docs can order the films, if they need them. If the hospital and Dr are connected in any way, the films might even be available to them through their on-line system. It is poissible and likely that even the OB/GYN will refer you to a surgeon for evaluation, and that would be normal. That still does not necessairly mean you have Cancer. The OB/GYN is a good place to start. Some of the bigger hospitals and OB/GYN practices have their own social workers that help women get "connected" to the appropriate services. It would not hurt to call and ask is they have a Maternal health social worker that could please call you back to help you navigate the system.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2007 03:24AM billiegirl wrote: I bought a yard of plain fleece at the fabric store and cut it into 4" wide strips so they are 4" x 36". Works great instead of cotton under-wrap and it washes nicely in a lingerie bag in both washer and dryer. I only wash outer night wraps every couple of months.

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 06:54AM billiegirl wrote: IBCspouse...I opted for the same plan as your wife. Couldn't afford a wig, until given a gift certificate by family, by which time I was done with Chemo. I asked the social worker about donation of hair from volunteers and she said that there are organizations that gladly accept donations (Locks of Love)but that the wigs made are reserved for children. Don't know if this is absolutely true-so am interested in what others know.
Posts.Title: Is anyone getting help from Komen? pinkpig fire

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2008 05:03AM billiegirl wrote: I had complications after surgery and then other un-cancer related health issues and was never able to return to work as an LPN even though I had only planned to be off for 2 weeks after my mast. I had insurance through my employer  for 1 year, thanks to accumulated sick leave, vacation time and donation of time from work mates.After 1 year, I had to officially resign. I qualified for SSDI, but not medicare ( which takes a couple of years) My health premiums were $600.00 per month plus co-pays, which used up my income from SSDI for a year.The Komen foundation did give me a grant for "rent" of $1000.00. I had gone to a Social Worker because I felt so overwhelmed and burdened financially and was literally living on credit cards. It never occured to me that any funds would be offered. That thousand dollars was really appreciated, but I too have wondered if many women actually get enough financial help to be able to get the care they need or lift the burden much. I have 5 daughters and a niece that have participated in the 3 Day numerous times and together have raised 10s of thousands for the Komen Foundation. I too would like to know more about how the money is divided up and think this should be researched a little more and the results posted as I am sure it is Public Info. I will see what I can find out...unless someone reading this already has the info.
Posts.Title: Is anyone getting help from Komen? pinkpig fire

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 02:21PM - edited Aug 18, 2009 02:23PM by billiegirl I read a book a while back...Women of Silence:The Emotional Healing of Breast Cancer.  I did not necessairly agree with everything the author suggested but did find it very interesting and  many descriptions of the typical Breast Cancer woman sure hit the nail on the head as far as my life and personality were concerned. Just one of many non-medical concepts out there. Interesting correlations between the high rate of breast cancer in women who are the fixing, caring, nurturing type and those that tend to take on the emotional pain and stress of others: ie nurses etc. There have also been ongoing studies/correlation between those who work the grave yard shift and their melatonon levels. Most night jobs for women are in nursing.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10
